result.markdown:
---
title: "Choosing things in dataframes"
editor: 
  markdown: 
    wrap: 72
---

## Packages

The usual:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```
:::


## Doing things with data frames

Let's go back to our Australian athletes:


::: {.cell}

:::



::: {.cell}

:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 13
   Sex    Sport   RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 female Netb~  4.56  13.3  42.2  13.6    20  19.2  49      11.3
 2 female Netb~  4.15   6    38    12.7    59  21.2 110.     25.3
 3 female Netb~  4.16   7.6  37.5  12.3    22  21.4  89      19.4
 4 female Netb~  4.32   6.4  37.7  12.3    30  21.0  98.3    19.6
 5 female Netb~  4.06   5.8  38.7  12.8    78  21.8 122.     23.1
 6 female Netb~  4.12   6.1  36.6  11.8    21  21.4  90.4    16.9
 7 female Netb~  4.17   5    37.4  12.7   109  21.5 107.     21.3
 8 female Netb~  3.8    6.6  36.5  12.4   102  24.4 157.     26.6
 9 female Netb~  3.96   5.5  36.3  12.4    71  22.6 101.     17.9
10 female Netb~  4.44   9.7  41.4  14.1    64  22.8 126.     25.0
# i 192 more rows
# i 3 more variables: LBM <dbl>, Ht <dbl>, Wt <dbl>
```


:::
:::


## Choosing a column


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(Sport)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 1
   Sport  
   <chr>  
 1 Netball
 2 Netball
 3 Netball
 4 Netball
 5 Netball
 6 Netball
 7 Netball
 8 Netball
 9 Netball
10 Netball
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Choosing several columns


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(Sport, Hg, BMI)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 3
   Sport      Hg   BMI
   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Netball  13.6  19.2
 2 Netball  12.7  21.2
 3 Netball  12.3  21.4
 4 Netball  12.3  21.0
 5 Netball  12.8  21.8
 6 Netball  11.8  21.4
 7 Netball  12.7  21.5
 8 Netball  12.4  24.4
 9 Netball  12.4  22.6
10 Netball  14.1  22.8
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Choosing consecutive columns


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(Sex:WCC, BMI)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 5
   Sex    Sport     RCC   WCC   BMI
   <chr>  <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1 female Netball  4.56  13.3  19.2
 2 female Netball  4.15   6    21.2
 3 female Netball  4.16   7.6  21.4
 4 female Netball  4.32   6.4  21.0
 5 female Netball  4.06   5.8  21.8
 6 female Netball  4.12   6.1  21.4
 7 female Netball  4.17   5    21.5
 8 female Netball  3.8    6.6  24.4
 9 female Netball  3.96   5.5  22.6
10 female Netball  4.44   9.7  22.8
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Choosing all-but some columns


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(-(RCC:LBM))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 4
   Sex    Sport      Ht    Wt
   <chr>  <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
 1 female Netball  177.  59.9
 2 female Netball  173.  63  
 3 female Netball  176   66.3
 4 female Netball  170.  60.7
 5 female Netball  183   72.9
 6 female Netball  178.  67.9
 7 female Netball  177.  67.5
 8 female Netball  174.  74.1
 9 female Netball  174.  68.2
10 female Netball  174.  68.8
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Select-helpers

Other ways to select columns: those whose name:

-   `starts_with` something
-   `ends_with` something
-   `contains` something
-   `matches` a "regular expression"
-   `everything()` select all the columns

## Columns whose names begin with S


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(starts_with("S"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 3
   Sex    Sport     SSF
   <chr>  <chr>   <dbl>
 1 female Netball  49  
 2 female Netball 110. 
 3 female Netball  89  
 4 female Netball  98.3
 5 female Netball 122. 
 6 female Netball  90.4
 7 female Netball 107. 
 8 female Netball 157. 
 9 female Netball 101. 
10 female Netball 126. 
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Columns whose names end with C

either uppercase or lowercase:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(ends_with("c"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 3
     RCC   WCC    Hc
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1  4.56  13.3  42.2
 2  4.15   6    38  
 3  4.16   7.6  37.5
 4  4.32   6.4  37.7
 5  4.06   5.8  38.7
 6  4.12   6.1  36.6
 7  4.17   5    37.4
 8  3.8    6.6  36.5
 9  3.96   5.5  36.3
10  4.44   9.7  41.4
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Case-sensitive

This works with any of the select-helpers:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(ends_with("C", ignore.case=FALSE))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 2
     RCC   WCC
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1  4.56  13.3
 2  4.15   6  
 3  4.16   7.6
 4  4.32   6.4
 5  4.06   5.8
 6  4.12   6.1
 7  4.17   5  
 8  3.8    6.6
 9  3.96   5.5
10  4.44   9.7
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Column names containing letter R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(contains("r"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 3
   Sport     RCC  Ferr
   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Netball  4.56    20
 2 Netball  4.15    59
 3 Netball  4.16    22
 4 Netball  4.32    30
 5 Netball  4.06    78
 6 Netball  4.12    21
 7 Netball  4.17   109
 8 Netball  3.8    102
 9 Netball  3.96    71
10 Netball  4.44    64
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Exactly two characters, ending with T

In regular expression terms, this is `^.t$`:

-   `^` means "start of text"
-   `.` means "exactly one character, but could be anything"
-   `t` means a literal letter t (uppercase or lowercase)
-   `$` means "end of text".

## Matching a regular expression


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(matches("^.t$"))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 2
      Ht    Wt
   <dbl> <dbl>
 1  177.  59.9
 2  173.  63  
 3  176   66.3
 4  170.  60.7
 5  183   72.9
 6  178.  67.9
 7  177.  67.5
 8  174.  74.1
 9  174.  68.2
10  174.  68.8
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Choosing columns by property

-   Use `where` as with summarizing several columns
-   eg, to choose text columns:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% select(where(is.character))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 2
   Sex    Sport  
   <chr>  <chr>  
 1 female Netball
 2 female Netball
 3 female Netball
 4 female Netball
 5 female Netball
 6 female Netball
 7 female Netball
 8 female Netball
 9 female Netball
10 female Netball
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Choosing rows by number


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% slice(16:25)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 10 x 13
   Sex    Sport   RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 female Netb~  4.25  10.7  39.5  13.2   127  24.5 157.     26.5
 2 female Netb~  4.46  10.9  39.7  13.7   102  24.0 116.     23.0
 3 female Netb~  4.4    9.3  40.4  13.6    86  26.2 182.     30.1
 4 female Netb~  4.83   8.4  41.8  13.4    40  20.0  71.6    13.9
 5 female Netb~  4.23   6.9  38.3  12.6    50  25.7 144.     26.6
 6 female Netb~  4.24   8.4  37.6  12.5    58  25.6 201.     35.5
 7 female Netb~  3.95   6.6  38.4  12.8    33  19.9  68.9    15.6
 8 female Netb~  4.03   8.5  37.7  13      51  23.4 104.     19.6
 9 female BBall  3.96   7.5  37.5  12.3    60  20.6 109.     19.8
10 female BBall  4.41   8.3  38.2  12.7    68  20.7 103.     21.3
# i 3 more variables: LBM <dbl>, Ht <dbl>, Wt <dbl>
```


:::
:::


## Non-consecutive rows


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% 
  slice(10, 13, 17, 42)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 4 x 13
  Sex    Sport    RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
  <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
1 female Netba~  4.44   9.7  41.4  14.1    64  22.8  126.    25.0
2 female Netba~  4.02   9.1  37.7  12.7   107  23.0   77     18.1
3 female Netba~  4.46  10.9  39.7  13.7   102  24.0  116.    23.0
4 female Row     4.37   8.1  41.8  14.3    53  23.5   98     21.8
# i 3 more variables: LBM <dbl>, Ht <dbl>, Wt <dbl>
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% slice_sample(n=8)

```

## Rows for which something is true


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% filter(Sport == "Tennis")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 11 x 13
   Sex    Sport   RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 female Tenn~  4      4.2  36.6  12      57  25.4 109     20.9 
 2 female Tenn~  4.4    4    40.8  13.9    73  22.1  98.1   19.6 
 3 female Tenn~  4.38   7.9  39.8  13.5    88  21.2  80.6   17.1

 5 female Tenn~  4.98   6.4  44.8  14.8    80  17.1  47.6   11.1 
 6 female Tenn~  5.16   7.2  44.3  14.5    88  18.3  61.9   12.9 
 7 female Tenn~  4.66   6.4  40.9  13.9   109  18.4  38.2    8.45
 8 male   Tenn~  5.66   8.3  50.2  17.7    38  23.8  56.5   10.0

11 male   Tenn~  5.38   6.3  46    15.7    32  21.1  34.9    6.26
# i 3 more variables: LBM <dbl>, Ht <dbl>, Wt <dbl>
```

## More complicated selections


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% filter(Sport == "Tennis", RCC < 5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 13
  Sex    Sport    RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
  <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
1 female Tennis  4      4.2  36.6  12      57  25.4 109     20.9 
2 female Tennis  4.4    4    40.8  13.9    73  22.1  98.1   19.6 
3 female Tennis  4.38   7.9  39.8  13.5    88  21.2  80.6   17.1 
4 female Tennis  4.08   6.6  37.8  12.1   182  20.5  68.3   15.3 
5 female Tennis  4.98   6.4  44.8  14.8    80  17.1  47.6   11.1

```

## Another way to do "and"


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% filter(Sport == "Tennis") %>% 
  filter(RCC < 5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 13
  Sex    Sport    RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
  <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>

2 female Tennis  4.4    4    40.8  13.9    73  22.1  98.1   19.6
```

## Either/Or


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% filter(Sport == "Tennis" | RCC > 5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


## Sorting into order


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% arrange(RCC)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


## Breaking ties by another variable


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% arrange(RCC, BMI)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 13
   Sex    Sport   RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 female Netb~  3.8    6.6  36.5  12.4   102  24.4 157.     26.6

 7 female BBall  3.96   7.5  37.5  12.3    60  20.6 109.     19.8

```

:::


## Descending order


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% arrange(desc(BMI))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 13
   Sex    Sport   RCC   WCC    Hc    Hg  Ferr   BMI   SSF `%Bfat`
   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 male   Field  5.48   6.2  48.2  16.3    94  34.4  82.7   13.9 
 2 male   Field  4.96   8.3  45.3  15.7   141  33.7 114.    17.4 
 3 male   Field  5.48   4.6  49.4  18     132  32.5  55.7    8.51
 4 female Field  4.75   7.5  43.8  15.2    90  31.9 132.    23.0 
 5 male   Field  5.01   8.9  46    15.9   212  30.2 112.    19.9 
 6 male   Field  5.01   8.9  46    15.9   212  30.2  96.9   18.1 
 7 male   Field  5.09   8.9  46.3  15.4    44  30.0  71.1   14.0 
 8 female Field  4.58   5.8  42.1  14.7   164  28.6 110.    21.3 
 9 female Field  4.51   9    39.7  14.3    36  28.1 136.    24.9 
10 male   WPolo  5.34   6.2  49.8  17.2   143  27.8  75.7   13.5 
# i 192 more rows
# i 3 more variables: LBM <dbl>, Ht <dbl>, Wt <dbl>
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

:::


## "The top ones"


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>%
  arrange(desc(Wt)) %>%
  slice(1:7) %>%
  select(Sport, Wt)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 2
  Sport    Wt
  <chr> <dbl>
1 Field  123.
2 BBall  114.
3 Field  111.
4 Field  108.
5 Field  103.
6 WPolo  101 
7 BBall  100.
```


:::
:::


## Another way


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% 
  slice_max(order_by = Wt, n=7) %>% 
  select(Sport, Wt)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 2
  Sport    Wt
  <chr> <dbl>
1 Field  123.
2 BBall  114.
3 Field  111.
4 Field  108.
5 Field  103.
6 WPolo  101 
7 BBall  100.
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% 
  slice_max(order_by = Wt, n=7) %>% 
  select(Sport, Ht) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 2
  Sport    Ht
  <chr> <dbl>
1 Field  189.
2 BBall  209.
3 Field  185 
4 Field  179.
5 Field  185.
6 WPolo  194.
7 BBall  199.
```


:::
:::


## Create new variables from old ones


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% 
  mutate(wt_lb = Wt * 2.2) %>% 
  select(Sport, Sex, Wt, wt_lb) %>% 
  arrange(Wt) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 202 x 4
   Sport   Sex       Wt wt_lb
   <chr>   <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Gym     female  37.8  83.2
 2 Gym     female  43.8  96.4
 3 Gym     female  45.1  99.2
 4 Tennis  female  45.8 101. 
 5 Tennis  female  47.4 104. 
 6 Gym     female  47.8 105. 
 7 T400m   female  49.2 108. 
 8 Row     female  49.8 110. 
 9 T400m   female  50.9 112. 
10 Netball female  51.9 114. 
# i 192 more rows
```


:::
:::


## Turning the result into a number

Output is always data frame unless you explicitly turn it into something
else, eg. the weight of the heaviest athlete, as a number:\normalsize


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% arrange(desc(Wt)) %>% pluck("Wt", 1) -> heavy
heavy
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 123.2
```


:::
:::


Or the 20 heaviest weights in descending order:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>%
  arrange(desc(Wt)) %>%
  slice(1:20) %>%
  pluck("Wt")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 [1] 123.20 113.70 111.30 108.20 102.70 101.00 100.20  98.00  97.90  97.90
[11]  97.00  96.90  96.30  94.80  94.80  94.70  94.70  94.60  94.25  94.20
```


:::
:::


## Another way to do the last one


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>%
  arrange(desc(Wt)) %>%
  slice(1:20) %>%
  pull("Wt") -> big_wt
big_wt
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
 [1] 123.20 113.70 111.30 108.20 102.70 101.00 100.20  98.00  97.90  97.90
[11]  97.00  96.90  96.30  94.80  94.80  94.70  94.70  94.60  94.25  94.20
```


:::
:::


`pull` grabs the column you name *as a vector* (of whatever it
contains).

## To find the mean height of the women athletes

Two ways:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>% group_by(Sex) %>% summarize(m = mean(Ht))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Sex        m
  <chr>  <dbl>
1 female  175.
2 male    186.
```


:::
:::



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
athletes %>%
  filter(Sex == "female") %>%
  summarize(w_mean = mean(Ht))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 x 1
  w_mean
   <dbl>
1   175.
```


:::
:::


## Summary of data selection/arrangement "verbs" {.smaller}

| Verb | Purpose |
|:------------------|:----------------------------------------------------|
| `select` | Choose columns |
| `slice` | Choose rows by number |
| `slice_sample` | Choose random rows |
| `slice_max` | Choose rows with largest values on a variable (also `slice_min`) |
| `filter` | Choose rows satisfying conditions |
| `arrange` | Sort in order by column(s) |
| `mutate` | Create new variables |
| `group_by` | Create groups to work with |
| `summarize` | Calculate summary statistics (by groups if defined) |
| `pluck` | Extract items from data frame |
| `pull` | Extract a single column from a data frame as a vector |

## Looking things up in another data frame

-   Suppose you are working in the nails department of a hardware store
    and you find that you have sold these items:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_url <- "http://ritsokiguess.site/datafiles/nail_sales.csv"
sales <- read_csv(my_url)
sales
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 x 2
  product_code sales
  <chr>        <dbl>
1 061-5344-6      10
2 161-0090-0       6
3 061-5388-2       2
4 161-0199-4       8
5 061-5375-2       5
6 061-4525-2       3
```


:::
:::


## Product descriptions and prices

-   but you don't remember what these product codes are, and you would
    like to know the total revenue from these sales.

-   Fortunately you found a list of product descriptions and prices:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_url <- "http://ritsokiguess.site/datafiles/nail_desc.csv"
desc <- read_csv(my_url)
desc
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 5
  product_code description    size        qty price
  <chr>        <chr>          <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
1 061-4525-2   spike nail     "10\""        1  1.49
2 061-5329-4   masonry nail   "1.5\""     112  8.19
3 061-5344-6   finishing nail "1\""      1298  6.99
4 061-5375-2   roofing nail   "1.25\""    192  6.99
5 061-5388-2   framing nail   "4\""        25  8.19
6 161-0090-0   wood nail      "1\""        25  2.39
7 161-0199-4   panel nail     "1-5/8\""    20  4.69
```


:::
:::


## The lookup

-   How do you "look up" the product codes to find the product
    descriptions and prices?
-   `left_join`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales %>% left_join(desc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 x 6
  product_code sales description    size        qty price
  <chr>        <dbl> <chr>          <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
1 061-5344-6      10 finishing nail "1\""      1298  6.99
2 161-0090-0       6 wood nail      "1\""        25  2.39
3 061-5388-2       2 framing nail   "4\""        25  8.19
4 161-0199-4       8 panel nail     "1-5/8\""    20  4.69
5 061-5375-2       5 roofing nail   "1.25\""    192  6.99
6 061-4525-2       3 spike nail     "10\""        1  1.49
```


:::
:::


## What we have

-   this looks up all the rows in the *first* dataframe that are also in
    the *second*.
-   by default matches all columns with same name in two dataframes
    (`product_code` here)
-   get *all* columns in *both* dataframes. The rows are the ones for
    that `product_code`.

So now can work out how much the total revenue was:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales %>% left_join(desc) %>% 
  mutate(product_revenue = sales*price) %>% 
  summarize(total_revenue = sum(product_revenue))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 x 1
  total_revenue
          <dbl>
1          178.
```


:::
:::


## More comments

-   if any product codes are not matched, you get NA in the added
    columns
-   anything in the *second* dataframe that was not in the first does
    not appear (here, any products that were not sold)
-   other variations (examples follow):
    -   if there are two columns with the same name in the two
        dataframes, and you only want to match on one, use `by` with one
        column name
    -   if the columns you want to look up have different names in the
        two dataframes, use `by` with a "named list"

## Matching on only some matching names

-   Suppose the `sales` dataframe *also* had a column `qty` (which was
    the quantity sold):


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales %>% rename("qty"="sales") -> sales1
sales1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 x 2
  product_code   qty
  <chr>        <dbl>
1 061-5344-6      10
2 161-0090-0       6
3 061-5388-2       2
4 161-0199-4       8
5 061-5375-2       5
6 061-4525-2       3
```


:::
:::


-   The `qty` in `sales1` is the quantity sold, but the `qty` in `desc`
    is the number of nails in a package. These should *not* be matched:
    they are different things.

## Matching only on product code


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales1 %>% 
  left_join(desc, join_by(product_code))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 x 6
  product_code qty.x description    size      qty.y price
  <chr>        <dbl> <chr>          <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
1 061-5344-6      10 finishing nail "1\""      1298  6.99
2 161-0090-0       6 wood nail      "1\""        25  2.39
3 061-5388-2       2 framing nail   "4\""        25  8.19
4 161-0199-4       8 panel nail     "1-5/8\""    20  4.69
5 061-5375-2       5 roofing nail   "1.25\""    192  6.99
6 061-4525-2       3 spike nail     "10\""        1  1.49
```


:::
:::


-   Get `qty.x` (from `sales1`) and `qty.y` (from `desc`).

## Matching on different names 1/2

-   Suppose the product code in `sales` was just `code`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales %>% rename("code" = "product_code") -> sales2
sales2
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 x 2
  code       sales
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 061-5344-6    10
2 161-0090-0     6
3 061-5388-2     2
4 161-0199-4     8
5 061-5375-2     5
6 061-4525-2     3
```


:::
:::


-   How to match the two product codes that have different names?

## Matching on different names 2/2

-   Use `join_by`, but like this:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales2 %>% 
  left_join(desc, join_by(code == product_code))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 6 x 6
  code       sales description    size        qty price
  <chr>      <dbl> <chr>          <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
1 061-5344-6    10 finishing nail "1\""      1298  6.99
2 161-0090-0     6 wood nail      "1\""        25  2.39
3 061-5388-2     2 framing nail   "4\""        25  8.19
4 161-0199-4     8 panel nail     "1-5/8\""    20  4.69
5 061-5375-2     5 roofing nail   "1.25\""    192  6.99
6 061-4525-2     3 spike nail     "10\""        1  1.49
```


:::
:::


## Other types of join

-   `right_join`: interchanges roles, looking up keys from second
    dataframe in first.
-   `anti_join`: give me all the rows in the first dataframe that are
    *not* in the second. (Use this eg. to see whether the product
    descriptions are incomplete.)
-   `full_join`: give me all the rows in both dataframes, with missings
    as needed.

## Full join here


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales %>% full_join(desc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 7 x 6
  product_code sales description    size        qty price
  <chr>        <dbl> <chr>          <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
1 061-5344-6      10 finishing nail "1\""      1298  6.99
2 161-0090-0       6 wood nail      "1\""        25  2.39
3 061-5388-2       2 framing nail   "4\""        25  8.19
4 161-0199-4       8 panel nail     "1-5/8\""    20  4.69
5 061-5375-2       5 roofing nail   "1.25\""    192  6.99
6 061-4525-2       3 spike nail     "10\""        1  1.49
7 061-5329-4      NA masonry nail   "1.5\""     112  8.19
```


:::
:::


-   The missing `sales` for "masonry nail" says that it was in the
    lookup table `desc`, but we didn't sell any.

## The same thing, but with `anti_join`

Anything in first df but not in second?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
desc %>% anti_join(sales)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 x 5
  product_code description  size      qty price
  <chr>        <chr>        <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
1 061-5329-4   masonry nail "1.5\""   112  8.19
```


:::
:::


Masonry nails are the only thing in our product description file that we
did not sell any of.

## The other way around


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sales %>% anti_join(desc)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 0 x 2
# i 2 variables: product_code <chr>, sales <dbl>
```


:::
:::


There was nothing we sold that was not in the description file.
